awd_titl_txt: Symposium on Defects and Strain Potential Enabled Emergent Behavior in 2-D Materials; Materials Research Society Fall Meeting; Boston, MA; Nov 28-Dec 3, 2021
awd_abstract_narration:
The grant provides registration, travel, and/or childcare support for 10 students to attend and present at the Symposium on Defects and Strain Potential Enabled Emergent Behavior in Two-Dimensional Materials, being held as part of the Materials Research Society (MRS) Fall Meeting in Boston, MA, November 28th – December 3rd, 2021. The symposium will focus on the mechanics of emergent behavior in two-dimensional materials due to mechanical straining and defect engineering. The awardees will be selected based on application including a brief resume, a statement of why they want to attend the conference, and conference abstract. While the selection will be open to all groups, members of underrepresented groups will be especially encouraged to apply. This award will benefit the nation through the education of a skilled and diverse engineering workforce better prepared to provide transformative solutions the challenges of their chosen fields.
 
This participation support is expected to benefit students' professional, scientific, and technical development as they present their research projects to the broader mechanics and material science community. Attendance at the wider conference will also provide the students an opportunity to learn about the engineering profession and state-of-the-art research in the wider fields. Students will have an opportunity to attend technical presentations, join the keynote and plenary sessions, and network with potential mentors, colleagues, and employers. This interactive experience will significantly broaden their education, increase their enthusiasm for their research topic, acquaint them with expectations for scientific careers, and expose them to new avenues for innovative research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
MRS 2021 Fall Meeting

Defects and Strain Potential Enabled Emergent Behavior in Two-Dimensional Materials (Symposium EQ07)

 

Objectives of the symposium

Strain and defect are effective means to achieve versatile functionalities in materials. Due to their weak interlayer coupling, several physical properties of van der Waals (vdW) solids show high sensitivity to strain modulation, e.g. bandgap change and phonon spectra shift. Recently, the moire superlattice and the atomic reconstruction were observed under periodic strain potential, which can lead to some emergent and intriguing properties, such as unconventional superconductivity and unique optoelectronic behaviors. Strain tuning of 2D materials is not limited by mechanical stretching/bending approach, wrinkling/crumpling of 2D materials or transferring onto patterned substrates. The hydrostatic compressive strain generated in a diamond anvil cell can reach to more than 10 percent, making possible the study of phenomena under extremely nonequilibrium conditions. Rich forms of defects are present in 2D materials, such as foreign atoms, wrinkles, grain boundaries, etc.

This symposium will cover a broad range of emergent properties in 2D materials enabled by strain and defect, including thermal, optical, electrical, magnetic properties, enabling the applications for electronics, plasmonics, spintronics, straintronics and valleytronics. The materials will include not only graphitic materials, transition metal dichalcogenides, but also some emerging families of ferromagnetic materials. Topics include:

  • Experimental investigation of thermal, electrical, optical and magnetic properties of 2D materials under strain
  • Theoretical and computational predictions of thermal, electrical, optical and magnetic transport of emerging 2D materials under strain
  • Emergence of new phases under extreme strain
  • Straintronics - Engineering 2D electronics through strain
  • Quantum defects in 2D materials
  • Defect-engineered 2D electronics
  • Reconstructed moire and soliton effects in 2D materials
  • Emergent/collective behavior with periodic strain potential modulation
  • Emerging applications of defect and strain potential engineered 2D materials in clean energy, environment, and advanced health care, etc.
  • New physics and properties associated with interfacial defect and strain engineering, including intercalation, adhesion, encapsulation, superlubricity, van der Waals confinement for chemical reaction, etc.

● A half-day tutorial lecture complementing this symposium on the fundamental science of the mechanical behavior and the moire superlattice of 2D materials.  

Highlights

This symposium featured a total of 56 oral presentations, of which 20 were invited (including 2 virtual tutorial lectures) and 36 were contributed. These presentations were grouped into 4 in-person (in Boston, MA) and 6 virtual sessions held in real-time, over a period of 6 days. The average in-person session attendance was about 30 people and the average virtual session attendance in real-time is about 15 people. The online sessions were recorded and put on MRS platform, Symposium highlights include:

  • Prof. Rui Huang (University of Texas - Austin) gave a comprehensive tutorial lecture on Mechanics of 2D Materials to those who are interested in the mechanical behavior and strain-engineering of 2D materials.
  • Prof. Pinshane Huang (University of Illinois - Urbana-Champaign), a female assistant professor, gave an outstanding invited talk on Designing the Bending Stiffness of 2D  Heterostructures. The talk started from controversies about the bending stiffness of 2D materials, and then a rigorous measurement of this crucial mechanical property by carefully designed experiments. The talk then compared the bending behavior of 2D materials to those of materials in the classical continuum regime and proposed new ways of engineering the functional properties of 2D materials based on this unique bending behavior.
  • Nirjhar Sarkar,  Ph.D. student from University of California - San Diego advised by Dr. Prabhakar R. Bandaru, delivered an interesting talk of harnessing the tip-induced mechanical deformation of 2D materials to tune the moire pattern in graphite. The title of the talk is Nanoscale probing technique based on tip induced local deformation of moire patterns on graphite surface by Scanning Tunneling Microscopy (STM)
  • Shayani Parida, Ph.D. student (female) from University of Connecticut and Los Alamos National Lab advised by Dr. Michael Pettes, delivered an excellent talk on Mechanical Tuning of the Electronic and Vibrational Properties of Epitaxial MoS2 Through Ion Beam Modification
  • Vera Zarubin, undergraduate from MIT, delivered an excellent talk entitled Defect Engineering of 2D van der Waals Materials for the Site-Selective Nucleation of Metal Nanoislands
  • Aniruddha Seal, undergraduate from National Institute of Science Education and Research, India, gave an excellent talk about his first-authored paper published on Nano Letters recently. The title of the talk is Modulating Water Slip Using Vacancy Defects - Towards Realistic Modeling of Hexagonal Boron Nitride Surfaces

Summary

This grant supports a total of 11 students and 3 postdocs (including 1 undergraduate student, and 4 from underrepresented minority groups) to participate in Symposium EQ07 Defects and Strain Potential Enabled Emergent Behavior in Two-Dimensional Materials at the 2021 Fall MRS Hybrid Meeting. Strain and defect engineering are effective means to tailor the functionalities of 2D materials. EQ07 was the session on this topic held at the MRS meeting for the 3rd consecutive year.

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 06/27/2022
Modified by: J. Ardie Butch Dillen
